Award.AwardTitle: Design and Analysis of Optimization Experiments with Internal Noise to Maximize Alignment of Carbon Nanotubes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the past several decades, carbon nanotubes (CNT) have risen to the forefront of scientific research due to their unique electrical, mechanical and optical properties. However, transferring these properties from nanoscale materials to industrial-scale products often requires alignment (orientation in the same direction) of CNT. One of the important consequences of alignment is improved conductivity, a highly desirable property in electro-chemical water treatment and closely associated with research endeavors to improve quality of drinking water. Therefore, identification of scalable and cost-effective experimental conditions that maximize alignment of CNT is an important research problem. This is addressed in the project.

The proposed research aims to establish statistical methodologies for designing and analyzing efficient experiments that determine conditions for maximizing alignment of CNT, when one or more input factors are prone to internal noise. The proposed research consists of three tasks, with particular focus on addressing the challenges arising from presence of factors with internal noise and complexity of the response surface. (i) Developing a Bayesian approach to response-surface optimization with noisy inputs. Such an approach allows the experimenter to combine data on output, controllable input, and uncontrollable input from different sources; is a natural way of incorporating expert knowledge into the analysis; and provides a natural framework for optimal design of experiments with noisy inputs. (ii) Efficient design of optimization experiments with noisy inputs. The research will focus on developing a comprehensive design strategy, which is a combination of model-free and Bayesian model-based optimal designs. The model-free design will address the challenges arising from internal noise and complex response surface. (iii) Demonstration and validation of the developed methodologies in the co-PI's lab. A series of experiments will be planned to apply the developed statistical methodology in an attempt to identify factors that trigger alignment of CNT and also to identify their optimum levels to maximize alignment. The proposed framework will allow an experimenter to effectively capture the transmission of uncertainty from input variables to output variables by combining data from different sources, and by utilizing a combination of model-free and model-based experimental designs for efficient exploration of complex response surfaces. From a material scientist's perspective, the proposed method will provide a much more accurate quantification of uncertainty, resulting in more reliable predictions about optimal process conditions as determined from laboratory experiments.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University New Brunswick
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

POR.DRECONTENT:
Identification of scalable and cost-effective experimental conditions that maximize alignment of CNT is an important research problem. One way to align the CNTs is to apply an electric field X. Thus experiments are conducted by varying the electric field X and measuring the alignment Y (see Figure 1). The experimental data is utilized to build an empirical relationship between Y and X (see Figure 2), from which the optimum electric field X that maximizes the alignment Y can be determined.

However, the electric field cannot be controlled precisely. For a given input voltage, it fluctuates around some nominal value. The fluctuations increase as the input voltage is larger. This is shown in the Figure 3. Such uncontrollable variation in experimental factors is typically known as "internal noise". In this case, X is the input factor with internal noise, fluctuating around a set value Z.

Thus, the chain of causation is Z -> X -> Y, and the problem is to determine optimal Z that maximizes Y. Both X and Y are random variables. In reality we cannot find a fixed optimal X, but we can find a fixed optimal Z to obtain a desired X (perhaps on an average) and consequently the maximum Y (also on an average). The questions that this research aimed at answering were:

  • Can we quantify severity of internal noise (a measure of how strong the noise is)?
  • Can we use such a measure to judge whether it is OK to ignore X completely, study the relationship Z->Y and determine the optimal Z?
  • Can we provide a unified statistical framework that will help us solve the problem of optimizing Z?

PRIMARY RESEARCH OUTPUT: APPLICATIONS TO MATERIAL SCIENCES AND BEYOND

 The research done in this project provided answers to the above questions. A statistical measure of severity of internal noise on a scale of zero to one has been developed. In the example of Figure 3, the measure was found to be very small (around .0025), which meant that one could ignore X in the relationship Z -> X -> Y and formulate the problem as identifying the relationship Z->Y instead.

Our research also provided a unified statistical framework that consisted of the following key elements:

  • Formulate a set of probabilistic models for X->Y and Z->X. 
  • Determine a performance measure (objective function) related to the distribution of Y that needs to be optimized. For example, the probability that Y exceeds a specified threshold value y*.
  • Develop an algorithm for optimizing the objective function and provide R codes that can be used by practitioners.

SECONDARY RESEARCH OUTPUT (CONTRIBUTIONS TO STATISTICS AND CAUSAL INFERENCE)

This problem was motivated by pre-processing experiments conducted on the CNTs prior to alignment. The process in which such experiments are conducted is shown in Figure 4. First the CNTS are randomly divided into two groups. A random sample (subgroup) of CNTs is drawn from each group and one treatment is applied to each subgroup. The results are then compared. This approach to experimentation is called: randomize first (split into two groups) and sample second.

Most statistical literature for analyzing experimental data to compare two interventions or treatments is based on settings where units from a large population is sampled, and then the sampled units are split into two groups with each being exposed to one intervention. Our research investigated whether, and under what conditions, the statistical inference procedures for the "randomize first, sample second" and "sample first, randomize second" should be the same.

CONTRIBUTIONS TO MATERIAL SCIENCE: APPLICATIONS TO CNT ALIGNMENT AND BEYOND

Optimal conditions for maximizing CNT alignments were identified by application of the proposed methodology. Some new exciting scientific results on the role of noise factors were obtained by analyzing data from new experiments. For example, Carbon nanotubes with larger mean length and diameter, smaller length and diameter variation, and higher oxygen content yielded resulted in better directional dependence. The results of the carbon nanotube alignment research were applied more broadly to water desalination applications, targeting developers of electrochemical water treatment processes. The results were published in leading material science journals like Carbon and Nanoscale.

BROADER IMPACTS

  • The main research output is not limited to applications in material science and is applicable to any branch of science and engineering.
  • The secondary research output opens up interesting problems at the interface of classical statistics and causal inference.
  • The reaserch output is closely associated with research endeavors to improve quality of drinking water - and thus potentially impacts the society. 
  • Education, training and collabration: Five doctoral students, among whom three are females, have benefitted from working on this project. Four of them have already graduated, and the research done with this award has, either directly or indirectly, formed parts of their thesis dissertations and resultant publications.
